p: Indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase (IDO), stimulated by IFN-Î³ and inhibited by TLR activation and allergens plays an important role in immune suppression (normally prevents hyper-inflammation and autoimmunity) by inhibiting T cell activation and polyclonal proliferation of T cells, mostly through degradation of tryptophan and kynurenines; its role in SARS-CoV2 infection was not explored but likely is important ( 86). Activation of IDO is strictly dependent on prior expression of Arginase 1 and the resulting polyamines, with immunosuppressive actions ( 87); while NO is an IDO inhibitor; the role of IDO in the SARS-CoV2 infection and its immune evasion has not yet been explored.
